who'd be interested in watching a live journalism debate between me and @Slasher, with a third-party moderator? y'know, if he fixes his mic.
@SeOh_ @lurppis_ @Slasher nothing "almost" about it ;]
@grunHD in fact, more information would be spread if the journalist would agree to do an in-depth piece rather than posting a tweet.
@grunHD no, not at all. there is no control over what information is spread in this scenario. we are simply talking about *when* it is said.
@BluemoonSC you make the journalist a reasonable value proposition that is best for the team, the journalist, and the fans as well.
@z1n0 right, which is why i made the point. i'm responding to the people who're saying "if you don't want news leaked, prevent the leaks."
@Ashwamedhayagna because to me, there's an obvious way to announce player transactions that benefits everyone (team, journalist, community).
@BluemoonSC a team that has no obligation to you, that you've just beaten in the race to sign a player, is not going to do such a favor.
it's not possible to "control the information" or prevent a leak with player transactions, because they by definition involve third-parties.
for example: you sign a free agent with multiple teams bidding on him. or you sign a new player away from a different team. the others know.
re: "if you don't want your news leaked, control your information better" - there are people outside of your company who'll find out.

RT @ApolloSC2: Regame #HSC
@Wenlei_Dai every sport has referees and/or admins for this exact reason.
@Wenlei_Dai players are supposed compete inside the game. they are not supposed to resolve disputes outside the game.
@Wenlei_Dai but there are other scenarios in which tournaments ask players to make these kinds of decisions, and that's simply unacceptable.
@Wenlei_Dai you can't blame it all on blizzard, man. sure, technology is responsible for issues stemming from disconnects.
@Wenlei_Dai players maintain pride and honor by winning in the game. not by being forced to decide whether or not to play a rematch.
@_Star_Galaxy_ and i agree with you that your link is not necessarily a bad way to handle it, but there was at least a defined procedure.
@_Star_Galaxy_ pros who are also at the same time competing in the tournament cannot play a part in making administrative decisions.
@_Star_Galaxy_ i understand what you're saying, but what's the point in having admins if you don't use them in the most important moments?
@SaintSnorlax @MonsterGaming i was just as critical of the last homestory cup, when greg benefitted from an equally disorganized situation.
@SaintSnorlax @MonsterGaming my criticism has nothing to do with it benefitting my player in this situation.
@SaintSnorlax @MonsterGaming XlorD is not at fault at all. the point is that players should not be put in the position to fight for anything
@TaKeSeN it would be one thing to select a group of pros (who wouldn't compete) to be admins before the tournament. that is not the case.
@TaKeSeN the pros are certainly qualified to analyze the game, but that is negated by the fact that they are also competing in the event.
@TaKeSeN a player should never, ever be put in a position where he or she has to make such a ruling.
@thisiskaztv players should never have to make such decisions.
@KimStrandli yes, i already did during the last homestory cup when it played in our favor.
yes, it should, @MonsterGaming. expect zero EG players at homestory cup vii if they don't finally use admins. casual is cool, sloppy is not.
this is why tournaments have rules and admins.
@TheMaelk no! :x
